question_text: What distinguishes autocatalytic (AC-type) from thermal decomposition (TD-type) reactions in terms of their kinetic behavior and heat release profiles during isothermal experiments?
standard_answer: Autocatalytic (AC-type) and thermal decomposition (TD-type) reactions exhibit fundamentally different kinetic behaviors and heat release profiles. AC-type reactions involve intermediate species that catalyze their own formation, creating positive feedback. In isothermal experiments, AC-type reactions show an induction period with gradually increasing heat flow as catalysts accumulate, reaching a maximum before decaying. This S-shaped profile reflects the autocatalytic mechanism where initial slow radical generation accelerates until catalyst concentration peaks. In contrast, TD-type reactions follow nth-order kinetics where heat flow immediately peaks at experiment start then decays exponentially, as reaction rate depends solely on reactant concentration without self-acceleration. The distinction arises from reaction mechanisms: AC-type involves chain-branching where radicals like ROO• from organic peroxides generate additional reactive species, while TD-type proceeds through direct molecular decomposition. For AC-type, the induction period represents slow accumulation of critical catalyst concentration, after which rapid autocatalytic decomposition occurs. This mechanistic difference has major safety implications, as AC-type substances can appear stable then suddenly undergo violent decomposition after sufficient induction time.
